entries.name: GPIO_read
entries.description: Reads the digital input value (HIGH or LOW) from a specified GPIO pin using MicroPython.

sections.description:
pin = Pin(pin_name, Pin.IN)
pin_value = pin.value()

pin_name: The GPIO pin identifier (e.g., PORT_A1).
Pin.IN: Configures the pin as an input pin.
Returns 1 if the pin is HIGH and 0 if the pin is LOW.

examples:
from klaw import *
from machine import Pin
from time import sleep

A1 = Pin(PORT_A1, Pin.IN)

while True:
    A1_val = A1.value()
    sleep(1)
    print(A1_val)

entries.name: digitalOutput
entries.description: Controls external components connected to a digital output pin. You can set the pin HIGH or LOW to turn devices on or off.

sections.description:
port = Pin(PORT_A1, Pin.OUT)
port.value(1)  # Set HIGH
port.value(0)  # Set LOW

PORT_A1: The external pin where the component is connected.
Pin.OUT: Configures the pin as a digital output.
value: 1 sets HIGH, 0 sets LOW.
No return value. Writing HIGH or LOW to the pin changes the state of the connected external component.

examples:
from klaw import PORT_A1, Pin
from time import sleep

port = Pin(PORT_A1, Pin.OUT)

while True:
    port.value(1)  # Turn on
    sleep(1)
    port.value(0)  # Turn off
    sleep(1)

entries.name: ADC_read
entries.description: Reads the analog input value from a specified GPIO pin using MicroPython’s ADC (Analog-to-Digital Converter).

sections.description:
adc = ADC(Pin(pin_name))
adc.atten(ADC.ATTN_11DB)
value = adc.read()

pin_name: The GPIO pin where the analog sensor is connected (e.g., PORT_A1).
ADC.ATTN_11DB: Configures the ADC input range up to 3.3V.
Returns an integer representing the analog input value, typically ranging from 0 to 4095 depending on the board and voltage.

examples:
from klaw import PORT_A1, Pin, ADC
from time import sleep

pot = ADC(Pin(PORT_A1))
pot.atten(ADC.ATTN_11DB)       # Full range: 3.3V

while True:
    pot_value = pot.read()
    print(pot_value)
    sleep(0.1)

entries.name: readUltrasonic
entries.description: Reads the distance measured by an external ultrasonic sensor connected to the A port of the Klaw device.

sections.description:
from klaw import UltraSonic
ul = UltraSonic()

# Ultrasonic sensor must be connected to the A port.

UltraSonic(): Initializes the ultrasonic sensor connected to the specified port.
read(): Reads the distance measured by the ultrasonic sensor in centimeters.
Returns an integer or float representing the distance in centimeters measured by the ultrasonic sensor.

examples:
from klaw import UltraSonic
from time import sleep

ul = UltraSonic()  # Ultrasonic sensor connected to A port

while True:
    print(ul.read())  # Reads and prints distance in cm
    sleep(1)

entries.name: pwmOutput
entries.description: Controls external components (e.g., LEDs, motors) using PWM signals on a specific pin. You can set the duty cycle to control brightness or speed.

sections.description:
pwm = PWM(klaw.PORT_A1)
pwm.duty_u16(duty)  # Set PWM duty cycle

PORT_A1: The external pin where the component is connected.
duty: Integer (0–65535) representing the PWM duty cycle. 32768 = 50% duty cycle.
No return value. The function adjusts the PWM signal to control brightness or speed of the connected component.

examples:
import klaw
from machine import PWM

pwm = PWM(klaw.PORT_A1)
pwm.duty_u16(32768)  # 50% duty cycle

entries.name: readKlawbSwitch
entries.description: Reads the value (pressed or not pressed) from the Klaw device's internal switches. These switches are onboard and do not require external wiring.

sections.description:
import klaw
from machine import Pin
switch = Pin(klaw.PORT_SWITCH1, Pin.IN)

klaw.PORT_SWITCH1: Constant that represents the first internal switch on the Klaw device.
Pin.IN: Configures the pin as an input to read the switch's state.
value(): Reads the current state of the switch. Returns 1 if pressed, 0 if not pressed.

Returns an integer:
1 – when the switch is pressed.
0 – when the switch is not pressed.

examples:
import klaw
from machine import Pin
from time import sleep

switch1 = Pin(klaw.PORT_SWITCH1, Pin.IN)  # '1' indicates the switch number

while True:
    print(switch1.value())
    sleep(1)

entries.name: readKlawbPotentiometer
entries.description: Reads the analog input values from the Klaw device's onboard potentiometer. These potentiometers are built into the Klaw device and do not require external wiring.

sections.description:
import klaw
from machine import ADC, Pin
pot = ADC(Pin(klaw.PORT_JY1))

klaw.PORT_JY1: Constant that represents the first internal potentiometer on the Klaw device.
ADC(): Configures the specified pin as an analog-to-digital converter to read analog values.
read(): Reads the current analog value of the potentiometer.
Returns an integer representing the analog value read from the potentiometer. The range typically depends on the device's ADC resolution (e.g., 0–4095 for 12-bit ADC).

examples:
import klaw
from machine import ADC, Pin
from time import sleep

pot1 = ADC(Pin(klaw.PORT_JY1))  # '1' indicates the potentiometer number

while True:
    print(pot1.read())
    sleep(1)

entries.name: klawInternalServoOutput
entries.description: Controls the internal servo motor connected to the Klaw device using PWM signals. You can rotate the servo to a specific angle between 0° and 180°.

sections.description:
import klaw
from machine import Pin, PWM
import time

servo = PWM(Pin(klaw.PORT_MOTOR1))
servo.freq(50)

# Define a helper function to move the servo
def move_servo(angle):
    min_pulse = 0.5
    max_pulse = 2.5
    pulse = min_pulse + (angle / 180) * (max_pulse - min_pulse)
    duty = int((pulse / 20) * 65535)
    servo.duty_u16(duty)

PORT_MOTOR1: Built-in port for connecting the servo motor.
angle: The angle to rotate the servo to, in degrees (0–180).
move_servo(angle): Moves the servo to the specified angle by converting the angle into the appropriate PWM duty cycle.
No return value. The servo motor physically rotates to the specified angle.

examples:
import klaw
from machine import Pin, PWM
import time

servo = PWM(Pin(klaw.PORT_MOTOR1))
servo.freq(50)

def move_servo(angle):
    min_pulse = 0.5
    max_pulse = 2.5
    pulse = min_pulse + (angle / 180) * (max_pulse - min_pulse)
    duty = int((pulse / 20) * 65535)
    servo.duty_u16(duty)

try:
    while True:
        for angle in range(0, 181, 10):
            move_servo(angle)
            time.sleep(0.1)
        for angle in range(180, -1, -10):
            move_servo(angle)
            time.sleep(0.1)
except KeyboardInterrupt:
    servo.deinit()  # Stop PWM when interrupted

entries.name: oledDisplay
entries.description: Controls an external OLED display connected to the board. You can set text at specific coordinates to show messages.

sections.description:
oled = Oled()
oled.set_text('string', x, y)
oled.show()

Oled(): Initializes the OLED display.
set_text():
  - string: The text to display (max 16 characters)
  - x: X-coordinate (0–128)
  - y: Y-coordinate (0–64)
show(): Updates the display to show the set text.
No return value. The text is displayed on the OLED screen at the specified coordinates.

examples:
from klaw import Oled

oled = Oled()

while True:
    oled.set_text('Free the MALLOCS !!!!', 10, 20)
    oled.show()

entries.name: servoOutput
entries.description: Controls an external servo motor connected to the board using PWM signals. The servo can be rotated to a specific angle between 0° and 180° by generating the appropriate PWM signal on the external port.

sections.description:
import klaw
from machine import Pin, PWM
import time

servo = PWM(Pin(klaw.PORT_A1))
servo.freq(50)

# Define a helper function to move the servo
def move_servo(angle):
    min_pulse = 0.5
    max_pulse = 2.5
    pulse = min_pulse + (angle / 180) * (max_pulse - min_pulse)
    duty = int((pulse / 20) * 65535)
    servo.duty_u16(duty)

PORT_A1: The port where the external servo is connected.
angle: The angle to rotate the servo to, in degrees (0–180).
move_servo(angle): Moves the external servo to the specified angle by converting the angle into the appropriate PWM duty cycle.
No return value. The connected external servo motor physically rotates to the specified angle.

examples:
import klaw
from machine import Pin, PWM
import time

servo = PWM(Pin(klaw.PORT_A1))
servo.freq(50)

def move_servo(angle):
    min_pulse = 0.5
    max_pulse = 2.5
    pulse = min_pulse + (angle / 180) * (max_pulse - min_pulse)
    duty = int((pulse / 20) * 65535)
    servo.duty_u16(duty)

try:
    while True:
        for angle in range(0, 181, 10):
            move_servo(angle)
            time.sleep(0.01)
        for angle in range(180, -1, -10):
            move_servo(angle)
            time.sleep(0.01)
except KeyboardInterrupt:
    servo.deinit()  # Stop PWM when interrupted

entries.name: sleep
entries.description: Pauses the execution of the program for a specified number of seconds. Useful for creating delays between actions.

sections.description:
from time import sleep
sleep(seconds)
seconds: A number representing the amount of time to pause the program. Can be an integer or a float (e.g., 1 for 1 second, 0.1 for 100 milliseconds).
No return value. The program simply waits for the specified duration before continuing execution.

examples:
from time import sleep

print('Start')
sleep(1)  # Wait for 1 second
print('End')

sections.description: int
0 (LOW) or 1 (HIGH)
